item.description: There was a time when the NYT covered both NY major league teams, but nowadays you have to turn to the Post for that? Too much Trump, not enough Mets. https://t.co/NljYsztoZm

item.title: Where's the feed?
item.description:
With all the talk today about feeds for Twitter with Markdown that work in any feed reader, it's time for me to show you something for real that isn't hype. üòÑ

This is the feed of my tweets.

https://t.co/0FnLWgnRKT

You can and should subscribe to it in any feed reader.

Let's find out how well this idea works in practice.

As they say...

Still diggin! ;-)

PS: More stuff tomorrow.
item.source:markdown:
With all the talk today about feeds for Twitter with Markdown that work in any feed reader, it's time for me to show you something for real that isn't hype. :smile:
This is the feed of my tweets.
https://t.co/0FnLWgnRKT
You can and should subscribe to it in any feed reader.
Let's find out how well this idea works in practice.
As they say...
Still diggin! ;-)
PS: More stuff tomorrow.

item.description: RSS and Markdown were made for Twitter or is it the other way around.
item.source:markdown: RSS and Markdown were made for Twitter or is it the other way around.

item.description: When I hear the word refactor in a sentence my internal copy editor wants to change it to factor. The re part is unnecessary.
item.source:markdown: When I hear the word refactor in a sentence my internal copy editor wants to change it to factor. The *re* part is unnecessary.

item.description: @jeffscott Threads are rolled up into one RSS item.

item.description: My philosophy is that everything people use to write is a writing tool, and can be made better by paying attention to how people use it and most important, how they want to use it.
item.source:markdown: My philosophy is that everything people use to write is a writing tool, and can be made better by paying attention to how people use it and most important, how they want to use it.

item.title: Twitter feeds should...
item.description:
• Understand threads.

  • Markdown.

  • You can use emoji short codes like üòÑ

  • Most important -- tweets can have titles since many feed readers expect them.

Imho that's a good first step in a bootstrap to integrate the Twitter and RSS worlds.

This is what that tweet looks like in a feed reader. https://t.co/KAuJsm4h8N
item.source:markdown:
* Understand threads.
* Markdown.
* You can use emoji short codes like :smile:
* Most important -- tweets can have titles since many feed readers expect them.
Imho that's a good first step in a bootstrap to integrate the Twitter and RSS worlds.
This is what that tweet looks like in a feed reader. https://t.co/KAuJsm4h8N

item.description: @verycoolhacker no. not yet. i'm putting up a server to help start the bootstrap.
item.source:markdown: @verycoolhacker no. not yet. i'm putting up a server to help start the bootstrap.

item.description:
@grovesprof you're about to get them back, and this time with titles, threads and markdown support.

@grovesprof Here's what a titled, tweeted markdown-enhanced rss item looks like in 2022. https://t.co/TXeVHORNcu

This is what the tweet looks like when it gets to Feedly. https://t.co/EVimY5s1Ua

An example of using Markdown in Twitter. https://t.co/RvY2djdwlA

Do you use a feed reader like NetNewsWire or Feedly?

The reason I ask is that soon you will be able to publish to all RSS readers from here in Twitter.

It really works, there's some serious innovation here, and fills in a missing piece that's been there since the mid-00s.

This is RSS and Twitter waking up after a long sleep.
item.source:markdown:
An example of using Markdown in Twitter. https://t.co/RvY2djdwlA
Do you use a feed reader like NetNewsWire or Feedly?
The reason I ask is that soon you will be able to publish to all RSS readers from here in Twitter.
It really works, there's some serious innovation here, and fills in a missing piece that's been there since the mid-00s.
This is RSS and Twitter waking up after a long sleep.
